actualResults.title: IDOR: Unauthorized Access to Other Users' Password Forms
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - valid vulnerability demonstrating IDOR at the password reset endpoint, allowing enumeration and access to any user's password reset form without authentication

actualResults.title: User Enumeration via Error Message Differentiation in Login Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - attackers can determine which usernames exist by observing different response patterns between valid and invalid usernames

actualResults.title: Lack of Brute Force Protection on Password Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - unlimited password attempts allowed without rate limiting, account lockout, or CAPTCHA, enabling brute force attacks

actualResults.title: Account Enumeration via Username Parameter Differentials
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - HTTP response code differentials (200 vs 302) enable account enumeration without authentication

actualResults.title: Hidden Form Field Exposure - User ID Information Disclosure
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - hidden form fields containing username and user_id are publicly discoverable, enabling account identification

actualResults.title: Missing Security Flags on JWT Cookie - XSS/MITM Vulnerability
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - auth_token cookie lacks HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags, enabling XSS token theft and MITM attacks

actualResults.title: Missing SameSite Cookie Flag Allows CSRF Attacks
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - session cookie missing SameSite flag allows CSRF attacks to perform unauthorized actions

actualResults.title: Missing Secure Flag on Session Cookie Allows Transmission Over HTTP
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - session cookie lacks Secure flag, enabling interception over unencrypted HTTP connections

actualResults.title: Hardcoded Credentials in HTML Comments
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - test account credentials (test:test) exposed in HTML comments are easily discoverable and functional

actualResults.title: User Full Name Disclosure on Password Page
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - user full names displayed without access control, enabling enumeration of personal information

actualResults.title: Sensitive User Information Exposed in JWT Token
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - JWT payload contains base64-encoded sensitive data (username, user_id, user_type) that is easily decoded

actualResults.title: Session Tokens Show Predictable Patterns - Potential Prediction Attack
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - session tokens use predictable timestamp components enabling potential token prediction attacks

actualResults.title: No Concurrent Session Limiting - Multiple Active Sessions Per User
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - no limits on concurrent sessions allow multiple simultaneous sessions per user without alerts

actualResults.title: User ID Exposed in Session Cookie (Unencrypted)
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - user_id exposed in easily decodable base64 session cookie enables IDOR attacks

actualResults.title: Authentication Bypass - Username Confusion in Password Form
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - submitted username in form is ignored, allowing authentication bypass with any username as long as password is correct

actualResults.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Logout Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - logout endpoint accepts CSRF attacks without token validation, enabling forced user logouts

actualResults.title: Server Information Disclosure via Allow Header
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - Allow header reveals supported HTTP methods, aiding attack surface mapping

actualResults.title: Logout Does Not Require CSRF Protection - CSRF Token Missing on Logout
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - duplicate of critical CSRF logout finding, documenting the missing token validation

actualResults.title: Unnecessary Server Header Information Disclosure
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - Server header reveals Apache version (2.4.65) and OS (Debian), enabling targeted exploit discovery

actualResults.title: Missing Session Invalidation on Logout
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - logout does not clear or expire session cookies, allowing session reuse after logout

actualResults.title: Double Logout Vulnerability - No Session State Validation
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - logout endpoint processes duplicate logout requests without checking session state

actualResults.title: Missing Rate Limiting and Account Lockout on Authentication Endpoints
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - authentication endpoint allows unlimited failed attempts without rate limiting or account lockout

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers
actualResults.assessment: Valid vulnerability - application missing X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP, HSTS, and other security headers

matched.actualTitle: JWT Signature Verification Disabled - Authentication Bypass
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same core vulnerability: JWT tokens are not properly verified for signatures, allowing attackers to manipulate token payloads including user_id claims. The expected finding specifically mentions JWT token decoding without signature verification to enable user_id manipulation, which directly corresponds to the actual finding that documents how signature verification is disabled, allowing modified payloads and complete token forgery.

matched.actualTitle: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) - Access Other Users' Dashboards
matched.matchReason: The IDOR finding demonstrates the practical exploitation of the JWT vulnerability: attackers modify the user_id in JWT tokens to access other users' dashboards. This is the direct impact described in the expected finding where user_id manipulation enables unauthorized access to other user accounts.
